reasoning: The position argues about whether compute bottlenecks (as an input complementarity/ρ<0 story) will prevent or substantially slow a software intelligence explosion. The critique mostly shifts to a downstream policy-translation claim: compute-cap regulation supposedly backfired by pushing activity into distributed/opaque channels. That is only weakly connected to the position’s core empirical/conceptual claim about compute as a bottleneck; even if true, it doesn’t show compute bottlenecks do (or don’t) slow an SIE—indeed, the critique’s core narrative (“caps didn’t stop progress”) is broadly compatible with the position’s thesis. As a refutation of the position, it therefore has low centrality and very low strength. Clarity is high: it’s clear what causal story is being asserted (policy lever → evasion/distribution → worse oversight). Correctness is limited because the key factual claims are speculative/future-historical and not supported with evidence here; still, the general possibility of regulatory evasion/opacity is plausible. The critique is mostly focused on one issue and contains relatively little pure filler.
title: Compute caps reroute progress into opaque pathways, worsening oversight without slowing capabilities
